text:
If a request requires authorization, mod_cache never caches the response.
However, section 14.8 of RFC 2616 says that a shared cached can cache under 
some situations, e.g. cache-control s-max-age/must-revalidate/public is 
specified.
creator: cer@acm.org
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Marking as an enhancement request ... "the server may" demonstrates we've
  simply never hacked together the code required to do so.  Patches are
  always welcome :-)

creator: Christopher.D.Knight@nasa.gov
text:
Unluckily, it looks like this will not be a simple patch...The code in question
is in the cache_url_handler which is run before the Cache-Control header can be
set in the headers_out table. :^(

...Or should cache_url_handler even check the Authorization header? Given that
the cache_in_filter does it's own check...
creator: Christopher.D.Knight@nasa.gov
Christopher.D.Knight@nasa.gov

text:
The same with Apache 2.1.6.

The check for Authorization header in cache_url_handler() should be at least
configurable (if not removed). cache_save_filter() does its own check for
Authorization header, but in standards compilant way.
creator: zybi@talex.pl
davi@apache.org
text:
It seems as of 2.2.4 the issue is fixed. mod_cache, in function cache_save_filter()
explicitly tests the Cache-Control exceptions.

If anyone feels this is still an issue, please re-open the bug.
